content.body:
There are vague future plans for object-literal decorators like `@(d) { x: 0 }`. So:
```js
x |> @(d)
{ x: 0 }
```
…also needs to be future proofed with an early error. We presumably should do the same with array literals. (And tuple/record literals when they come.)

Blocks are fine.
```js
x |> @(d)
{ 0 }
```
…only has one reasonable interpretation (as `x |> @(d); { 0 }`).

I don’t think there’s anything else on the expression level that might get decorated…Maybe identifiers? Right now there are only plans for parameter identifiers so maybe we also ban this too:

```js
x |> @(d)
y
```

content.body: So the plan is to use a cover grammar ShortCircuitExpression `|>` CoverPipeBodyOrDecoratedExpression. PipeBody is the usual. DecoratedExpression is something like DecoratorList Expression. It’s an early error if DecoratedExpression covers CoverPipeBodyOrDecoratedExpression.
content.formatted_body: So the plan is to use a cover grammar ShortCircuitExpression |> CoverPipeBodyOrDecoratedExpression. PipeBody is the usual. DecoratedExpression is something like DecoratorList Expression. It’s an early error if DecoratedExpression covers CoverPipeBodyOrDecoratedExpression.

content.body: I have heard about obejct property decorators, but never about decorators for the whole object. It can just be a function call?
Not sure. Take a look at https://github.com/tc39/proposal-decorators/blob/master/EXTENSIONS.md#object-literal-and-property-decorators-and-annotations.
It feels a bit that pipeline is taking into account other possible proposals in a way that many other proposals don't.

content.body: Since (if?) we’re going with `@` as the topic reference, I think it’s reasonable to try to future proof against any potential future conflict with future decorator extensions.
content.formatted_body: Since (if?) we’re going with @ as the topic reference, I think it’s reasonable to try to future proof against any potential future conflict with future decorator extensions.

content.body: It’s only decorators really that pipe has to be careful about.
* The only proposal that that pipe has to be careful about is decorators.

m.new_content.body: The only proposal that that pipe has to be careful about is decorators.

content.body: It though that we have to be careful about infix operators too.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It though that we have to be careful about infix operators too.

content.body: (…Well, I guess there’s the dataflow stuff in general. Like how pipe will not advance unless bind-this advances. But I’m talking about syntax only.)

> <@pokute:matrix.org> It though that we have to be careful about infix operators too.

I don’t think we have to be careful about future non-identifier infix operators. It’s future infix operators that have to be careful of pipe (or specifically of the `@` topic). And those future proposals will be able to use some simple lookahead rules when they get proposed (https://github.com/tc39/proposal-pipeline-operator/issues/91#issuecomment-1085006912), and it should be fine.

In reply to @pokute:matrix.org
It though that we have to be careful about infix operators too.

content.body: I wish we could just ban ASI after pipes
If that would be enough
I’ll think about if we can do that instead.
But the problem isn’t that ASI is happening. It’s that developers might expect ASI to happen when it wouldn’t.
content.formatted_body: But the problem isn’t that ASI is happening. It’s that developers might expect ASI to happen when it wouldn’t.

content.body:
```js
x |> @(d)
class C {}
```
Here, ASI would *not* happen. It would be equivalent to:
```js
x |> (@(d) class C {})
```
But a developer might expect ASI to happen, as if it were:
```js
x |> @(d); class C {}
```
content.formatted_body:
x |> @(d)
class C {}

Here, ASI would not happen. It would be equivalent to:

x |> (@(d) class C {})

But a developer might expect ASI to happen, as if it were:

x |> @(d); class C {}

content.body:
Well, that's the same expectation in
```
a = b
[c].map(f)
```
If you use ASI, learn it and don't complain 🤷
Yes, that is true, heh.
But there is also future-proofing.
ASI *does* happen…until object-literal decorators get added.
content.formatted_body: ASI does happen…until object-literal decorators get added.

content.body: We could ask to the other delegates if anyone feels like all those decorators extensions are a possibility on the future

I think it’s reasonable to just ban PipeExpression : ShortCircuitExpression `|>` DecoratorList Expression.
Come to think of it, we probably don’t even need a cover grammar.
content.formatted_body:
I think it’s reasonable to just ban PipeExpression : ShortCircuitExpression |> DecoratorList Expression.
Come to think of it, we probably don’t even need a cover grammar.

content.body: That's a great idea
